content.description: You are asked to identify pitch patterns. After a question is announced, you will have ten seconds to read the relevant choices. It is important that you read the choices carefully before the example is played. Each example will be played twice, with a brief pause between playings.
content.question: Which of the following is played?

choices.label: The figure presents a score with a Bass staff. There is no key signature or time signature. There is only one measure. The rhythm of the staff is a set three whole notes. The pitches of the notes are B flat 2, E flat 3 and F 3.

The figure presents a score with a Bass staff. There is no key signature or time signature. There is only one measure. The rhythm of the staff is a set three whole notes. The pitches of the notes are B flat 2, E 3 and F 3.

The figure presents a score with a Bass staff. There is no key signature or time signature. There is only one measure. The rhythm of the staff is a set three whole notes. The pitches of the notes are B flat 2, F 3 and G flat 3.

The figure presents a score with a Bass staff. There is no key signature or time signature. There is only one measure. The rhythm of the staff is a set three whole notes. The pitches of the notes are B flat 2, F 3 and G 3.

content.answer: The figure presents a score with a Bass staff. There is no key signature or time signature. There is only one measure. The rhythm of the staff is a set three whole notes. The pitches of the notes are B flat 2, E flat 3 and F 3.

unit.text: 1: Music Fundamentals I - Pitch, Major Scales and Key Signatures, Rhythm, Meter, and Expressive Elements

skill.text: Skill 1.A: Use symbols and terms to describe features of pitch in performed music, including pitch patterns and relationships, melodic features, chords, harmonic progressions, and cadences.
